column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: AGL's report includes AGL Energy Limited (the Company or Parent Entity) and the entities it controls.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: AGL's report includes information about performance from 1 July 2022 to 30 June 2023.
AGL's comparative balances have been restated to reflect historical structural changes in the closed group, with no impact on the consolidated group's financials.
Deloitte provided external assurance for AGL's report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships

column7: The FY23 employee engagement score increased 10 percentage points from FY22 to 67%.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: The Nominations Committee assists the Board in fulfilling its responsibilities to Shareholders by making recommendations about the optimal composition of the Board. The Committee's purpose is to review and recommend matters relating to optimal board composition, director independence, and succession planning to the Board.
column20: Nominations Committee, Shareholder responsibilities, Board recommendations

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mrs Patricia McKenzie is the chair of AGL's Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column13: The Board oversees AGL's cyber and business resilience capabilities. It reviews management reports on emerging sources of risk and mitigation measures in place to deal with those risks, including cyber security and climate change.
column20: Board oversight, Cyber resilience, Business Resilience\t

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: AGL developed a sound working knowledge and understanding of the subject matter through past executive or management roles, extensive on-the-job application of skills in Board and Committee activities and through training and professional development activities.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Board is responsible for AGL's overall governance. Its role is to safeguard AGL's interests and protect and foster sustainable value creation while considering the reasonable interests of shareholders, employees, customers, the communities in which AGL operates, and other relevant stakeholders.\t

column13: AGL considers a Director to be independent if the Director is independent of management and free of any interest, position, or relationship that might influence or reasonably be perceived to influence. In a material respect, this is their capacity to bring independent judgement to bear on issues before the Board and to act in the best interests of AGL as a whole rather than in the interests of an individual shareholder or other party.
column20: Director, Management independence, Conflict of interest, Independent judgment

column13: AGL has a Code of Conduct that applies to AGL and its Directors, employees and contractors and sets out the standards of responsibility and ethical conduct required of 'our People'. The Code of Conduct was refreshed in FY23 to reflect AGL's new purpose and values. AGL's commitment under the Code of Conduct is to manage conflicts of interest.\t
column20: Code of Conduct, Directors, Employees, Standards of Responsibility\t

column13: AGL's enterprise-wide risk management program is aligned with the principles and requirements of the international standard for risk management (ISO 31000). Through this program, we identify factors critical to the successful delivery of our strategy and our ability to continue creating value in the future.
column20: Enterprise-wide risk management program, Risk management, ISO 31000

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: AGL seeks to maintain a Board with a broad range of skills, knowledge and experience necessary to provide adequate oversight over management and guide the company's strategic direction. The Board uses a skills matrix to identify the essential skills and experience the AGL Board seeks to achieve in its membership.
column20: Skills matrix, Oversight, Strategic direction\n

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Board regularly reviews its performance, the performance of Board Committees and the performance of individual Directors. Given the appointment of five Non-Executive Directors during FY23, the Board decided it was most appropriate to undertake an internal review of its performance in FY23. The Board intends to undertake an externally facilitated Board Review in FY24 once the entire Board has been working together for at least 12 months.
column20: Board performance, review, Board Committees, Directors, Non-Executive Directors

column13: The refined remuneration framework for AGL aims to enhance focus on strategic measures for achieving long-term decarbonisation objectives and supporting future growth. It also focuses on the operational core to generate strong cashflows, thereby supporting future growth and shareholder returns, aiming to create long-term shareholder value.
column20: Remuneration framework, strategic measures, decarbonisation objectives, future growth

column13: Following the 2022 strategic review, publication and approval of the inaugural CTAP, the AGL Board committed to a review of the remuneration framework to ensure that it continues to be fit-for-purpose and delivers long-term value for shareholders whilst driving the transition. The review of the Framework included the performance metrics in both the short-term and long-term incentives, as aligning these with strategy is critical to delivering against both annual and longer-term objectives.
column20: Strategic review, CTAP, Board, remuneration framework

column7: Our strategy includes transitioning our energy portfolio by exiting coal 10 years earlier than planned and an ambition to add ~12 GW of new renewable generation and firming capacity by the end of 2035."

column13: AGL is committed to complying with all applicable laws and regulations and has a robust enterprise-wide compliance framework to manage our compliance requirements, including privacy-related ones.
column20: Compliance Framework, Compliance, Laws

column13: AGL invested significant time consulting with governments and a wide range of stakeholders following the release of our Climate Transition Action Plan (CTAP) and our plans to accelerate our exit from coal-fired generation. Governments and AGL need to understand how our commitments impact governments' renewable energy and net-zero goals and the implications of policy settings on the energy transition.
column20: Climate Transition Action Plan (CTAP), Coal-fired generation, Stakeholder consultation, Governments

column13: AGL established a Green Finance Framework, which sets out the process by which we have issued debt on an ongoing basis to fund capital expenditures for new firming capacity and renewable energy assets. The Framework will support the delivery of AGL's CTAP, driving more efficient access to capital for 'green' projects that meet the eligibility criteria specified in the Framework, which is guided by best practice principles and guidelines.
column20: Green Finance Framework, Firming capacity, Renewable energy assets

column13: AGL's governance framework establishes the policy guidelines under which energy hedging activities are conducted. The policy allows for commercial optimisation of the portfolio provided that AGL adheres to overall earnings-at-risk limits that reflect its risk appetite.\t
column20: Governance framework, Energy hedging activities, Policy guidelines

column13: AGL used risk indicators to identify and validate our modern slavery risk exposure in critical areas of our operations and supply chains. AGL has identified key risk areas for modern slavery: offshore labour, the solar supply chain, and sourcing batteries and solar-related products.\t
column20: Risk indicators, modern slavery, operations, supply chains

column13: The Audit & Risk Management Committee oversees the issues, incidents, and risks identified by management in Group Audits, compliance reports, and risk reports. It ensures clear accountability for and effective closure of the relevant problems.
column20: Audit & Risk Management Committee, Risks, Group Audit,\nCompliance

column13: AGL is committed to ensuring that risk management practices are embedded into all business processes and operations to drive consistent, effective, accountable action, decision-making, and management practices. The Board has adopted a Risk Management Policy that sets out AGL's objectives for risk management and clearly articulates the responsibilities of all AGL's people in managing risks.
column20: Risk management practices, Business processes, Risk Management Policy

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: AGL's Whistleblower Protection Policy encourages reporting of suspected unethical, illegal or undesirable behaviour and promotes a culture of honest and ethical conduct. Athirdpartywhistleblower service provider facilitates AGL's employees and other stakeholders speaking up regarding any concerns that AGL or its people are failing to meet ethical or legal standards.
column20: Whistleblower Protection Policy, Reporting, Suspected behaviour, Ethical Conduct\t

column7: During FY23, there were 30 Environmental Regulatory Reportable (ERR) incidents and four administrative non-compliance events.

AGL is a member of several industry associations that provide a range of benefits, including access to industry information and analysis, relationship building, and an additional avenue to prosecute unified industry views on energy, climate change and related policies

column13: AGL strives to make a net positive social, economic and environmental contribution to the communities in which we operate. AGL proactively engages with our stakeholders on relevant issues in ways most appropriate to each group, prioritising the establishment of positive, respectful and transparent relationships. It is essential to AGL that we build trust in our stakeholders by engaging openly with them and by having them recognise and consider their views in our decision-making.
column20: Stakeholders, engagement, net positive contribution, social

column13: AGL invests in our communities through a structured community investment program. In FY23, AGL invested approximately $4.8 million.\t
column20: Community investment, Communities, Operational areas
